@drbecky_ You and others could apply for time and then the entire world could have immediate access to the data â€” with zero kowtowing to national, institutional or other exclusivity.

@drbecky_ Thanks for replying :-)

I appreciate that many observed subjects are niche/esoteric.

It just seems that exclusive access periods artificially enforce market-dynamics and meritocratic individualism. 

Iâ€™d love more top researchers to critique academy social justice shortcomings.

@drbecky_ Institutional pursuit of enlightenment knowledge seems compromised by incentivizing researchers with financial and status rewards if they â€œplay the gameâ€ around monetization of knowledge and status.

Immediate global access to all cosmological observations would help to undo that

@drbecky_ Itâ€™s as if the politics of grant-seeking, exposure-seeking, university brand-building and principal-investigator-historic-impact-aspiration gets normalized as an ethical baseline justify artificially gatekeeping results with exclusive access periods. Canâ€™t cosmology do better?

@drbecky_ Why do they make scientists compete for time on these telescopes (in exchange for exclusive results access) like a sort-of career Hunger Games? 

Canâ€™t all results be immediately public and bypass any sense of researcher ego or careerism? Itâ€™s more selfless and humanist that way.

For context, this is the problematic @NASAWebb data access policy, which uses contrived access-scarcity for little good reason beyond control of press narratives and career/institution  exposure. Interpretation of data should be a global plebiscite.
https://t.co/9VCYw5VNdQ

All @NASAWebb raw subject data should be made available to all researchers and the public in real-time. Competitive, â€œmeritâ€ based access reinforces academic careerism, politicking and STEM inequality. @NASA should pick humanity over the Ivory Tower and cosmic nationalism. #JWST

@Galliway_ @_mecyver Whatâ€™s an equivalent of a 1990s celebration of distressed attire (e.g, Nirvana, Rage Against The Machine) in todayâ€™s urban spaces? Is there balkanization between that aesthetic and â€œshoeheadsâ€ or â€œGucci/flyâ€ adjective-users? Did one side lose a culture war? Is distressed profane?

@_mecyver I wonder: Did punk and grunge mature in the 1980s and 1990s as aesthetics that celebrated a visually distressed â€œbeaterâ€ look as a critique of the failures of prosperity? Can that ethos coexist with a love for the immaculate and undamaged as a symbol of achievement and wellness?

@beaniemaxi Itâ€™s also controversial because we prioritize animating oppression as something that trickles up from interpersonal derisionâ€” rather than down from unequal political and economic power. Mincing words preserves a mythological, linear agency in impacting the substance of wrongness.

@beaniemaxi I DO think poap whitelisting sometimes gets deployed as a bait-and-switch to inorganically bribe â€œorganicâ€ Discord and Twitter engagement, and that the fake-organic-reach scarcity of centralized/algorithmic social media worsens this problem â€” but whitelisting has more complexity.

@beaniemaxi Canâ€™t wallet whitelisting be part of a comprehensive, legitimate security process to enact human verification and deter botting? Especially in the absence of Discord and other centralized processes facilitating this reliably in the decentralized economy?
